newsitem.title: USA: U.S. June cash crude turns weaker against July WTI.
newsitem.headline: U.S. June cash crude turns weaker against July WTI.

text.p: U.S. cash crudes were steady late Friday morning in quiet pre-holiday trading, while domestic grade differentials strengthened on reports of a pipeline shutdown in the U.S. Gulf.
U.S. markets will be closed Monday for observance of the Memorial Day holiday.
Cash dealers said June West Texas Intermediate/Cushing continued to lose ground against a steady July WTI, with last deals on the "roll" pegged at minus 40 cents.
July WTI/Cushing was unchanged at $21.85-95 a barrel.
Friday marks the final day for June crude business.

Louisiana Offshore Oil Port (LOOP) officials said the LOCAP pipeline link to the key Capline system remained shut Friday after experiencing a leak on Thursday. Some 800,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude throughput was idled while repairs and an investigation into the cause of the incident were conducted.
LOOP sources said the line should be back in operation later Friday, but traders said it was possible the offshore link may be out for more than one day.
LOOP said force majeure declarations were not needed, as it would be able to compensate for lost production over the course of the month.
Grades were quiet in the June frame, with Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James talked at vague numbers, 10-30 cents under benchmark.
July LLS was sold at eight cents under July WTI, slightly firmer than Thursday deals.
Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire was marked at a 30-40 cents discount for June business, and at a negative 50 cents against July WTI.
West Texas Sour/Midland firmed to only a $1.20-30 discount for June, but volumes were thin and prices skewed.
Traders said firmers CFDs, a slight narrowing in the Brent-WTI spread and the LOOP troubles backed the firming trend for grades.
